text:
E16/320  Mt  Walton  was  taken  out  to  cover  a  concealed  greenstone  sequence  in 
 remote  country  140  kilometres  northeast  of  Southern  Cross.    The  intention  was  to 
 carry out geochemical reconnaissance sampling for gold and base metals in order to 
 locate indications of any anomaly which would justify more detailed evaluation. 
 2.0  LOCATION AND ACCESS 
 The  Mt  Walton  tenement  lies  some  55  kilometres  Southwest  of  Davyhurst  in  the 
 Coolgardie  Mineral  Field  of  WA.    It  is  located  in  the  north  western  part  of  the 
 Kalgoorlie 1:250,000 map sheet.  Access is west, along poor tracks off the Menzies-
 Evanston Road from Davy Hurst. 
 A  single  old  exploration  rack  passes  northwards  directly  east  of    the  tenement 
 although  this  is  in  very  poor  condition  and  difficulty  may  be  experienced  crossing 
 3.0  TOPOGRAPHY AND VEGETATION 
 The area is generally flat to gently rolling, with occasional low ridges of outcrop in 
 the north east.  Drainage courses are essentially absent, while small, shallow claypans 
 occur in the south and east. 
 Much of the area is covered by dense low scrub – dominantly Grevillia and Ti-tree – 
 although stands of Eucalyptus are present and increase to the north.

16.text: Bedrock  is  covered  by  a  variety  of  Pleistocene  to  Recent  sediments  consisting  of

17.text: yellow Aeolian sands and paler alluvial to lacustrine sands, silts and clays.  Ironstone

18.text: gravel nodules occur within yellow sands in the north eastern part of the area.

20.text: No gold mineralisation has been recorded although a cluster of small pits occurs 10

23.text: Detailed  aeromagnetics  suggests  that  a  more  subtle  parallel  NNW-SSE  linear

24.text: magnetic feature terminating with a fold at its northern end runs, under cover, through

25.text: the centre of E16/320 and could be ultramafic in nature rather than banded chert and

26.text: jaspilite with minor ultramafic as occurs to the east and north east.

30.text: Nickel exploration in ultramafic rocks to the north east has been reported by Jododex

31.text: (1972)  and  Kennecott  (1972),  although  no  significant  mineralisation  was  located.

32.text: Kennecott  noted  local  development  of  small,  copper  and  silver-bearing  limonitic-

33.text: quartz veins in apparent felsic volcanics in the far north of the area, although these

34.text: veins were thought to be of granitic origin.  The last known exploration was carried

35.text: out to the east by SOG who briefly explored the area for gold in 1993 and 1994.

41.text: A  NOAA  image  for  the  area  was  obtained  and  interpreted  by  a  consultant,  Peter

42.text: Wilson.  A structural interpretation was prepared showing inferred outcrop areas and

43.text: numerous  faults  or  lineaments.    The  majority  of  these  trend  in  the  northeast  sector

44.text: although west to northwest trends are also common, particularly in the north of the

45.text: area.    These  structures  may  or  may  not  have  any  relevance  for  Archaean  gold

46.text: mineralisation, but have been used for targeting some of the geochemical sampling.

text:
Bedrock  is  covered  by  a  variety  of  Pleistocene  to  Recent  sediments  consisting  of 
 yellow Aeolian sands and paler alluvial to lacustrine sands, silts and clays.  Ironstone 
 gravel nodules occur within yellow sands in the north eastern part of the area. 
 No gold mineralisation has been recorded although a cluster of small pits occurs 10 
 Detailed  aeromagnetics  suggests  that  a  more  subtle  parallel  NNW-SSE  linear 
 magnetic feature terminating with a fold at its northern end runs, under cover, through 
 the centre of E16/320 and could be ultramafic in nature rather than banded chert and 
 jaspilite with minor ultramafic as occurs to the east and north east. 
 6.1  PREVIOUS EXPLORATION 
 Nickel exploration in ultramafic rocks to the north east has been reported by Jododex 
 (1972)  and  Kennecott  (1972),  although  no  significant  mineralisation  was  located.  
 Kennecott  noted  local  development  of  small,  copper  and  silver-bearing  limonitic-
 quartz veins in apparent felsic volcanics in the far north of the area, although these 
 veins were thought to be of granitic origin.  The last known exploration was carried 
 out to the east by SOG who briefly explored the area for gold in 1993 and 1994. 
 6.2  EXPLORATION BY SOG, 1993/94 
 A  NOAA  image  for  the  area  was  obtained  and  interpreted  by  a  consultant,  Peter 
 Wilson.  A structural interpretation was prepared showing inferred outcrop areas and 
 numerous  faults  or  lineaments.    The  majority  of  these  trend  in  the  northeast  sector 
 although west to northwest trends are also common, particularly in the north of the 
 area.    These  structures  may  or  may  not  have  any  relevance  for  Archaean  gold 
 mineralisation, but have been used for targeting some of the geochemical sampling.

These samples lie in the vicinity of the small cupriferous quartz-limonite veins located 
 by  Kennecott  and  the  geochemical  association  appears  to  support  a  granite-related 
 No  sampling  was  carried  out  in  the  northern  tenement,  where  thicker  transported 
 cover would eliminate any bedrock geochemical response. 
 A total of 119 RAB holes (1,559m) was drilled on eight traverses across the eastern 
 greenstone belt at intervals of 3 to 8 kilometres, with drill hole spacing varying from 
 50 to 200 metres.  These traverses were sited to intersect structural targets interpreted 
 from NOAA imagery or aeromagnetic data, with three purposes in mind, namely: 
 to accurately locate greenstone boundaries and examine bedrock lithologies; 
 to determine the thickness of cover sediments; 
 (iii)  to obtain indications of at least low level gold (or base metal) mineralisation. 
 In situ laterite and bedrock samples were submitted for low level gold analysis (Aqua 
 regia, graphite furnace AA – 1ppb detection limit).  All samples were run for Cu, Pb, 
 Zn, Mn, Fe, Cr, Ni and As by ICP. 
 Superficial cover varies from 0 to 22 metres thick and lies on an irregular bedrock 
 surface.  Sediments consist of sands and silts with silcrete silica-cemented horizons 
 No  in  situ  laterite  was  recognised:  instead,  Quaternary  deposits  lie  on  heavily 
 weathered,  leached  clays  or  on  saprolite  representing  a  partially  stripped  laterite 
 The eastern greenstone sequence varies from 200 metres to over 2000 metres wide, 
 with the variation due to structural and/or intrusive activity.  A general stratigraphic 
 succession consists of mafic and high magnesium volcanics and ultramafic intrusives 
 in the west, passing into fine-grained (tuffaceous?) sediments with local banded iron 
 formation  in  the  east.    Drill  cuttings  were  logged  as  massive  or  foliated,  but  no

13.text: Laterite  samples  were  collected  only  in  the  southern  part  of  the  property,  but  were

14.text: logged as being transported.  Although they carry no obvious signature of nearby gold

15.text: or base metal mineralisation, not too much can be read into these results.

text:
related to underlying mafic rocks and appear to have no economic significance.  Lead 
 values  are  low,  while  chrome  and  nickel  can  be  useful  in  mapping  ultramafic  and 
 mafic lithologies where clay weathering is advanced. 
 Laterite  samples  were  collected  only  in  the  southern  part  of  the  property,  but  were 
 logged as being transported.  Although they carry no obvious signature of nearby gold 
 or base metal mineralisation, not too much can be read into these results. 
 7.0  CONCLUSIONS 
 Preliminary  exploration  activities  consisting  of  NOAA  imagery  and  broad-spaced 
 aeromagnetic  interpretation  followed  by  reconnaissance  scale  soil  and  bedrock 
 geochemical sampling have improved understanding of the Ularring greenstone belt, 
 but  have  failed  to  detect  any  sign  of  significant  gold  or  base  metal  mineralisation.  
 This work was thought to down-grade the economic potential of the area, although the 
 very wide spacing of the sample lines means that much of the greenstone belt remains 
 untested. There is no indication that work conducted by SOG included the concealed 
 magnetic features occurring on E16/320. 
 Given  the  degree  of  cover  in  the  area,  a  detailed  aeromagnetic  survey  would  be 
 required to create worthwhile targets for additional testing. 
 8.0  WORK CARRIED OUT THIS REPORTING YEAR 
 The area has not seen any activity for over 13 years and any tracks that previously 
 existed were totally overgrown and inaccessible.  A considerable amount of clearing 
 was required to gain access to the tenement. 
 A search of previous exploration was carried out, but all work seems to have been 
 focused on the main greenstone belt to the east. 
 Field  reconnaissance  was  completed  to  verify  the  previous  exploration  activities 
 although very thick bush prevented extensive coverage.   
 Geological field inspection of the project area targeted the central part of the tenement 
 to  the  west  of  the  Ularring  greenstone  belt  which  itself  largely  disappears  beneath 
 sandplain  cover,  and  has  been  less  thoroughly  explored  than  the  relatively  well-
 explored northern part of the belt. 
 Earlier  reconnaissance  had  shown  that  existing  access  tracks  to  the  tenement  were 
 disused  and  heavily  overgrown,  both  from  the  south,  from  the  Great  Eastern

12.text: Inspection  of  E16/320  tried  to  identify  areas  of  pisolitic  lags  which  might  enable

13.text: geochemical sampling in the future.  Such lags are entirely absent in areas of thickly

14.text: vegetated yellow dune sands, but are developed to some extent along the margins of

15.text: the ridge which defines the greenstone belt where sand cover is thin or absent.

17.text: Some overgrown east-west grid lines were noted probably to undertake soil sampling

18.text: but no results have been discovered on open file. Field inspection would suggest that

19.text: this  sort  of  work  would  be  ineffective  given  the  nature  of  the  surface  cover.

20.text: Exploration next field season would include ground magnetics, auger sampling and

21.text: geochemical  bed  rock  drilling.  A  considerable  amount  of  track  clearing  in  this

22.text: extremely  difficult  and  isolated  terrain  will  be  required  to  accomplish  any  of  these

 Inspection  of  E16/320  tried  to  identify  areas  of  pisolitic  lags  which  might  enable 
 geochemical sampling in the future.  Such lags are entirely absent in areas of thickly 
 vegetated yellow dune sands, but are developed to some extent along the margins of 
 the ridge which defines the greenstone belt where sand cover is thin or absent. 
 Some overgrown east-west grid lines were noted probably to undertake soil sampling 
 but no results have been discovered on open file. Field inspection would suggest that 
 this  sort  of  work  would  be  ineffective  given  the  nature  of  the  surface  cover. 
 Exploration next field season would include ground magnetics, auger sampling and 
 geochemical  bed  rock  drilling.  A  considerable  amount  of  track  clearing  in  this 
 extremely  difficult  and  isolated  terrain  will  be  required  to  accomplish  any  of  these
